ğŸ“– Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
And He (Exalted) said: 'On that day, the people will emerge in scattered groups to be shown their deeds. So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it.' And He (Exalted) said: 'Then every soul (Nafs) will be fully compensated for what it earned, and they will not be wronged.' And He (Exalted) said: 'On the day when every soul (Nafs) will find what it did of good present [before it], and what it did of evil, it will wish that between it and that [evil] was a great distance. And Allah warns you of Himself.' And He (Exalted) said: 'And know that Allah knows what is in your souls (Anfus), so beware of Him.' So the possessors of insight (Arbab al-Basa'ir) from among the servants recognized that Allah (Exalted) is lying in wait for them, and that they will be scrutinized in the accounting and held accountable for atom's weights of thoughts (Khatarat) and glances (Lahazat). And they realized that nothing will save them from these dangers except adhering to self-accounting (Muhasabah) and sincere self-observation (Muraqabah), and demanding from the soul (Nafs) in breaths (Anfas) and movements (Harakat), and accounting it for thoughts (Khatarat) and glances (Lahazat). For whoever accounts his soul (Nafs) before being accounted for, his accounting on the Day of Resurrection (Qiyamah) will be lightened, and his answer will be present at the questioning, and his return and outcome will be good. And whoever does not account his soul (Nafs), his regrets will persist, and his pauses in the gathering places of the Day of Resurrection (Qiyamah) will be prolonged, and his evil deeds will lead him to disgrace and contempt.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
So if you know that good character traits (Akhlaq) are sometimes by nature (Tab') and innate disposition (Fitrah), sometimes by habitual practice (I'tiyad) of beautiful actions, and sometimes by observing the masters of beautiful deeds and accompanying them - they being the companions of good (Qurana' al-Khayr) and brothers of righteousness (Ikhwan al-Salah) - for indeed nature steals from nature both evil and good. So whoever has the three aspects manifest in his case until he becomes one possessing virtue (Fadilah) by nature, habit, and learning, he is at the utmost degree of virtue. And whoever is base (Radhil) by nature and happens to have evil companions, so he learns from them and the means of evil become easy for him until he becomes accustomed to them, he is at the utmost distance from Allah the Exalted. And between these two ranks are those who differ in these aspects, and for each degree in nearness (Qurb) and distance (Bu'd) according to what his form (Surah) and state (Hal) necessitate: "So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it, and Allah did not wrong them, but they were wronging their own souls (Anfus)."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
The narration of the man who came to learn and reached the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it.' He said: 'This is sufficient for me,' and departed. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The man departed as a jurist (faqih).' Reported by Abu Dawud, al-Nasa'i in al-Kubra, Ibn Hibban, and al-Hakim who authenticated it from the narration of Abdullah ibn Amr who said: A man came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: 'Recite to me, O Messenger of Allah...' In it: So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) recited to him 'When the earth is shaken' until he finished it. The man said: 'By the One who sent you with the truth, I will never add to these two.' Then the man turned away.
